Description.val: This line item funds modifications to MH-60 Series aircraft. The MH-60 Series FY 2019 Inventory is comprised of: 8 HH-60H, 261 MH-60S, 269 MH-60R. The HH-60H is used for dedicated Special Operations Forces (SOF) support and will be replaced by MH-60S in FY 2019.  Primary missions of the MH-60S include Surface Warfare, SOF Support, Personnel Recovery and Airborne Mine Countermeasures (AMCM).  Additional missions include Combat Logistics, Vertical Replenishment, Search and Rescue, Humanitarian Assistance/Disaster Response, and Airhead Operations.  The primary missions of the MH-60R are Anti-Submarine Warfare, Electronic Warfare, and Surface Warfare.  Secondary missions include Vertical Replenishment and Search and Rescue.  The overall goal of the modifications budget is for Safety Related Systems Upgrades, AMCM/Armed Helo (Correction of Deficiencies) for the MH-60S, Warfighter upgrades for the MH-60R, Warfighter upgrades for the MH-60S and, MH-60 Aircraft obsolescence.

Justification.val: The FY 2020 funding request is for critical safety, obsolescence, avionics, weapons and mission system modifications.  The increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 supports the following efforts: (OSIP 001-06) Ramp up of ADTS/MMI A and B kit procurements and trainer upgrades for ADTS/MMI and System Configuration 18 to incorporate VOR/ILS capability; (OSIP 018-12) commencement of non recurring engineering efforts to address end-of-life obsolescence issues with the MH-60 Advanced Flight Control Computer and stabilator amplifier and trainer and support equipment upgrades required for the MC/FMC obsolescence effort.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: Safety Related Systems Upgrade funds modifications to improve the safety of operating MH-60 Series aircraft in all operations.  In addition to those modifications specifically cited below, this Operational Safety Improvement Program provides the vehicle to expeditiously fund and correct MH-60 Series engine, airframe and avionics safety-related deficiencies (Hazard Risk Index 1-20).  Future modifications will include modification of rotor damper bearings with elastomeric bearings leading to increased component life, replacing the current non-locking rescue hook with a locking rescue hook to improve safety, mandated controlled-flight-into-terrain (CFIT) avoidance systems, mandated mid-air-collision avoidance capabilities (MCAC), mandated  crash data recording capabilities, improved tail gear box bevel gear mesh patterns to reduce catastrophic damage under increased load conditions, and MH-60S gunner seats.
Areas of potential OSIP modifications being investigated for future improvements include: 1) Power & Propulsion systems/Engines  (gearboxes, Auxiliary Power Unit (APU), T700, rotors, fuel systems, and dampers),   2) Aircrew Survivability (integration for seating, harness, hearing), and Safety issues (integration for landing gear, instrument/navigation, fuel, electrical/wiring, guns, weapons, dynamic flight control components, mission computers, Advanced Flight Control Computer (AFCS), Radar Altimeter (RADALT), crash worthy seating, emergency lighting, and hydraulic systems) and 3) Airframe/Avionics (soundproofing, landing gear, and rescue hoist, cockpit lighting/searchlights, and Airborne Low Frequency Sonar (ALFS)).
Additionally, the safety modifications include aircraft avionics and mission systems that enable overland operations in degraded visual flight environments (DVE) that are associated with unimproved terrain, both day and night, and in all weather conditions.  This includes terrain avoidance warning systems, precision overland navigation awareness displays, enhanced radar laser detection systems for obstacle and power line avoidance, and additional developmental items that pertain to operations in degraded visual environments.
DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The MH-60 series currently has 35 active Safety Action Records being monitored across all MH-60 series aircraft.  As solutions become available the aircraft modifications will be implemented.

JUSTIFICATION FOR REQUIREMENTS AND CHANGES: OSIP 009-03 baseline funding decreases by $6.4M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to completion of critical MH-60S Gunner Seats in FY 2019 to reduce or eliminate the detrimental impacts to the health (back injury), preservation and well being of the aircrew.

Current Active Modifications:
1. T700 Engine; 2. Aircrew Survivability Kits; 3. Airframe Safety Kits; 4. Tail Gearbox Sight Gauges

[OTHER SUPPORT] Cost element 3.5 (Other Support) funding is required for acquisition, configuration/documentation management, scheduling of aircraft and installation activities, engineering, and test support required to incorporate safety modifications on the MH-60R/S aircraft.

Name.@footnote: Cost element 1.1.2 (Night Vision Device) procured kits are being installed in FY 2018 and FY 2019 due to unforeseen fleet unavailability for required Planned Maintenance Interval (PMI) to complete installation.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: Night Vision Device (NVD) Kits

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  Based on Developmental and Operational Testing, Fleet aircraft require modifications to correct identified deficiencies incorporated in production aircraft.  These modifications include corrections to Night Vision Device Exterior Lighting and Airborne Mine Countermeasures (AMCM) Mission Equipment. Current retrofit plan includes AMCM Mission Equipment which are not procured on a one-for-one basis with the A kit modifications. No install is required.  Night Vision Device Capable Aircraft Lighting will be retrofitted on 134 Aircraft.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The MH-60S aircraft completed Operational Evaluation in March 2002; Milestone III was completed 12 August 2002.  

JUSTIFICATION FOR REQUIREMENTS AND CHANGES:  OSIP 016-04 baseline funding decreases by $0.2M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to completion of efforts. FY 2019 funding for Night Vision device installation and associated support is required as a result of aircraft availability.

[Other Support] Cost element 3.6 (Other Support) funding is required for acquisition, configuration/documentation management, scheduling of aircraft and installation activities required to incorporate the Armed Helo/AMCM modifications.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: VOR INSTRUMENT LANDING SYSTEM (ILS)
Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: ADTS/MMI Kit

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The MH-60R provides warfighting effectiveness in the primary mission areas of Anti-Submarine Warfare, Electronic Warfare, and Surface Warfare, including fast attack craft/fast in-shore attack craft (FAC/FIAC) threat response.  Secondary MH-60R mission areas include search and rescue, vertical replenishment, naval surface fire support, logistics support, naval special warfare, strike warfare, personnel transport, and medical evacuation.

This OSIP funds modifications to the MH-60R Series aircraft to include airframe structures, avionics, weapons and mission systems.   

The land based Precision Approach Radar (PAR) is the only precision approach available to the MH-60R and is slated to be replaced by Joint Precision Approach Landing System (JPALS) at Naval Air Stations.  The Very high frequency Omnidirectional Radio range (VOR) navigation capability included with the ILS system provides instrument navigation after disestablishment of Tactical Air Command and Navigation system in the Continental United States.  Instrument Landing System (ILS) provides precision approach capability ashore and to supplement currently available military PAR controlled approaches. 

Automatic Radar Periscope Detection and Discriminator (ARPDD) provides the MH-60R the capability to detect very small, low visibility targets, such as periscopes and small vessels, and alert the aircrew to their presence from long distances, reducing aircrew workload and increasing battle group survivability.  The AN/APS-153 MMR consists of the Signal Data Processor/ARPDD Enhanced Processor, Receiver Transmitter (R/T), Antenna Pedestal, Antenna Array, and IFF R/T retrofits.  Retrofits to the IFF R/T will provide Mode 5 capability.

Advanced Data Transfer System (ADTS) provides high-capacity storage and transfer of data with multi-level security enabling moving map integration and replacing obsolete components. 

The Acoustic Subsystem is a key component to meeting MH-60R Anti-Submarine Warfare mission requirements. The Acoustic Subsystem consists of Acoustic Processer, Airborne Low Frequency Sonar (ALFS) Transmitter/Receiver, Reeling Machines, Reeling Machine Interface Unit, Reeling Machine Control Unit, Transducer Assembly, and reel & cable. Night Vision Device improvements will incorporate enhancements to the Thunderstorm Light, ALFS Light, Recovery, Assist, Securing, and Traversing Panel, and Search Light.  The MH-60R/ALFS is the primary ASW sensor in the Carrier Strike Group. ALFS reliability improvement efforts include but are not limited to the following: (1) Reeling machine sonar cable monitoring system to allow for immediate clearing of cable miswraps prior to cable damage, (2) Sonar Transmitter Receiver upgrade to provide cable uplink dynamic equalizer to increase overall usable life of the sonar cable, (3) Transducer Assembly reliability improvement: Hydraulic Motor and stave retention, and (4) Reeling Machine locking device limit switches and aux electric motor power relay.  

Aircraft Ship Integrated Secure and Traverse System (ASIST) has been cancelled due to DDG 1000 decision to not incorporate full ASIST on the ship.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Automatic Radar Periscope Detection and Discriminator (ARPDD) capability was approved with CPD 260-05 dated 28 November 2005.  CDR was completed April 2009.  Milestones include contractor test completed in December 2010, developmental test completed in December 2011, and operational test started in July 2012. 
                                                                                                                        METHOD OF IMPLEMENTATION: ARPDD and ADTS/MMI are "O" Level Installs. 
 
JUSTIFICATION FOR REQUIREMENTS AND CHANGES: OSIP 001-06 baseline funding increases $16.7M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to the ramp up of ADTS/MMI A and B kit procurements to provide critical storage and data transfer capability to the fleet and training equipment requirements for ADTS/MMI and System Configuration 18, which adds VOR/ILS capability to training devices, and an increase in quantity of VOR/ILS installs.

[ALFS Reliability Improvements] Cost element 2.1.2 (ALFS Reliability) efforts contain different quantities and scope each year resulting in overall cost variability.

[ADTS/MMI RME Kit] ADTS/MMI unit cost is more expensive on the MH-60R than the MH-60S due to the requirement for an additional digital transfer unit in each kit.

[ARPDD O&A] ARPDD Over & Above requirements occur approximately two years after B kit procurement.

[TRAINING EQUIPMENT] Cost element 3.3 (Training Equipment) increase in FY 2020 and FY 2021 for required System Configuration 18 and ADTS/MMI training device modifications.

[OTHER SUPPORT] Cost element 3.6 (Other Support) funding is required for acquisition, configuration/documentation management, scheduling of aircraft and installation activities, engineering, and test support required to incorporate the modifications on the MH-60R aircraft.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:   The basic MH-60S conducts search and rescue, vertical replenishment, Humanitarian Assistance/Disaster Response, and airhead operations. Armed Helicopter and Airborne Mine Countermeasures (AMCM) have been added as primary mission areas for the MH-60S as block upgrades to the platform.  Armed Helicopter upgrades provide Surface Warfare and Maritime Interdiction Operations capability to address Fast Attack Craft / Fast In-shore Attack Craft (FAC/FIAC) threat, as well as Special Warfare Support and Combat Search and Rescue.  AMCM provides the Littoral Combat Ship with the airborne portion of the Mine Countermeasures Mission Package. MH-60S secondary roles include torpedo and drone recovery, noncombatant evacuation operations, and Sea Air Land (SEAL) team and Explosive Ordnance Disposal support.

This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds modifications to the MH-60S series airframe structures, avionics and mission systems, and provides for the retrofit of aircraft, training devices, and support equipment.
Armed Helo Block 3A includes airframe provisions, removable mission kits, and trainer updates into Block 3A aircraft to provide capability against the FAC/FIAC threat and support Naval Special Warfare, and includes the following systems:  Fixed Forward Firing Weapons (FFFW) guns and rockets, Helmet Display Targeting System (HDTS), and Full Motion Video capable Data Link.

ECP 4039 is required to accommodate aircraft structural loads imposed by the addition of the AMCM and Block 3 Armed Helo capabilities.

ECP H-60-111 incorporates Downed Aviator Locator System (DALS) in all Block 3 aircraft. 

Advanced Data Transfer System (ADTS) provides high-capacity storage and transfer of data with multi-level security enabling moving map integration and replacing obsolete components. 

Funding will support the modifications to the H-60 series aircraft that operate in the CENTCOM area of responsibility to incorporate a Distributed Aperture Infrared Countermeasure (DAIRCM) capability in order to fulfill a CENTCOM JUONS for improved Missile Warning (MW) Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE) with an inexhaustible countermeasure capability to pace the threat from the latest Surface to Air Weapons due to the operational environment.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The MH-60S Aircraft completed Milestone III in August 2002.  Armed Helo achieved Initial Operational Capability (IOC) in June 2007. AMCM: Initial Operational Test & Evaluation (IOT&E) extended to complete by FY 2021 for Littoral Combat Ship.   
 

JUSTIFICATION FOR REQUIREMENTS AND CHANGES: OSIP 009-07 baseline funding decreases $19.8M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to reduction in HDTS and ECP H-60-111 kit procurements, as well as completion of the FMV NRE effort.

[HDTS RME] Changes to HDTS RME quantities are due to the increase in required Primary Aircraft Authorized (PAA) and associated squadron pilots needed to support expanded LCS deployments.  Adjusting the total quantity of RME units from 120 to 181 provides HDTS capability in a sufficient number of Block 3 aircraft to meet operational and training requirements.

[HDTS Helmet Tracker (HTK)] Changes to HDTS HTK quantities are due to the increase in required Primary Aircraft Authorized (PAA) and associated squadron pilots needed to support expanded LCS deployments. Adjusting the total quantity of HTK units from 480 to 868 aligns procurement with the number of pilots assigned to HSC squadrons

[Training Equipment] Cost element 3.3 (Training Equipment) FY 2020 and FY 2021 funding is required for System Configuration 18 and ADTS/MMI trainer modifications.

[Other Support] Cost element 3.6 (Other Support) funding is required for acquisition, configuration/documentation management, scheduling of aircraft and installation activities, engineering, and test support required to incorporate the modifications on the MH-60S aircraft.

Name.@footnote: Cost element 3.3 (Training Equipment) FY 2019 thru FY 2021 funding is required for Mission Computer/Flight Management Computer (MC/FMC) trainer modifications.
Cost Element 3.4 (Support Equipment) FY 2020 funding for Operational Test Program Set (OTPS) for mission computer.

Cost element 3.6 (Other Support) funding is required for acquisition, configuration/documentation management, engineering, and test support required to incorporate obsolescence modifications on the MH-60R/S aircraft.

Cost element 2.1.1 (Avionics B Kit) efforts contain different quantities and scope each year resulting in overall cost variability. Funding in FY 2022 thru FY 2024 for obsolescence efforts regarding Advanced Flight Control Computer, Stabilator amplifier, Active Vibration Control Computer, and high definition displays.

Cost element 2.1.2 (Air Vehicle B Kit) efforts contain different quantities and scope each year resulting in overall cost variability. Funding in FY 2024 is for obsolescence component kits for the Hydraulic Control Module, Fire Extinguisher Logic Module, and Distributor Box, Main Rotor Blade Fold.
Cost element 2.1.3 (Mission Systems B Kit) funding in FY 2024 is for obsolescence component kits for the RAST control panel.
Cost element 2.1.4 (Weapons B Kit) funding in FY 2024 is for obsolescence component kits for the Armament Control Indicator.

Cost Element 2.2.1 (MH-60R/S Obsolescence NRE) funding in FY 2020 and FY 2021 is for non recurring engineering to address end-of-life obsolescence issues with the MH-60 Advanced Flight Control Computer and stabilator amplifier. FY 2022 to FY 2024 funding supports end-of-life obsolescence issues with the Armament Control Indicator, Control Monitor Panel, Hydraulic Control Module, Fire Extinguisher Logic Module Assembly, Active Vibration Control Computer , Distributor Box Main Rotor Blade Fold, De-Ice Controller/System, Technical Insert Acoustic Processor, Recovery Assist Secure and Traverse Control Panel, and high definition displays.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The MH-60 Aircraft are included in the Department of the Navy Aviation Plan through calendar year 2045. The MH-60 aircraft sustainment strategy targets initiatives to remedy the top age-related maintenance degraders fatigue life limiters, obsolescence and safety issues that impede the aircraft's ability to operate into the future. This effort will sustain the MH-60 in an affordable manner until the follow-on aircraft becomes available. The increase in this Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) reflects the increasing shift towards aircraft modifications as the sole means to incorporate changes on the MH-60 Aircraft. This program implements a concentrated effort to utilize improvements to the MH-60 component obsolescence (e.g. mission computers), structural limitations (e.g. tail pylon, canted bulkhead, station 308 structural improvement), aircrew safety systems, and aircraft wiring analysis health. 

In order to mitigate the risk of Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) the MH-60 program has a proactive plan to manage the risk associated with obsolescence issues.  DMSMS includes material obsolescence which may occur at the part, module, component, equipment, or other system indenture level. These situations may cause material shortages that endanger MH-60 capabilities, readiness, and life cycle support.  Preliminary efforts include the incorporation of system bill of materials (BOM) for active monitoring into predictive tools to prioritize and determine risk associated with possible DMSMS occurrences.  When issues arise, the solution involves procurement from alternate sources, substitution of components, life of type buys, emulation of components, or ultimately system redesign requiring the modification of MH-60 systems. Obsolescence kit procurements will be focused in the areas of air vehicle, mission systems, avionics and weapons. 

Aircraft modification/replacement of the Single Board Computers (SBCs) in the Gen III and Gen VI Mission Computers/Flight Mission Computers in the MH-60R/S will allow for future software builds.   The current computers have obsolescence issues and do not have the memory or processing speed for new software builds to include the RNP/RNAV capability.  

MH-60R/S is the lead platform for Multifunctional Information Distribution System (MIDS) Block Upgrade 2 (BU2), in support of Battle Group Tactical Data Link Network Centric Warfare. MH-60R/S will procure MIDS BU2 upgrades to support Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Frequency Remapping (FR) and National Security Administration (NSA) Crypto Modernization (CM) mandates by 2020.

JUSTIFICATION FOR REQUIREMENTS AND CHANGES:  OSIP 018-12 baseline funding increases by $28.8M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 to support commencement of non recurring engineering efforts to address end-of-life obsolescence issues with the MH-60 Advanced Flight Control Computer and stabilator amplifier and trainer and support equipment upgrades required for the MC/FMC obsolescence effort.
